title: All retroviruses are RNA viruses, but are all RNA viruses retroviruses? - Quora

response.answer_text: No, not even close. There are a large number of non-retroviral RNA viruses, many which cause disease that you might be familiar with, including common and exotic ones. Influenza viruses, which are segmented, negative stranded enveloped viruses.Picornaviruses, positive stranded non- enveloped viruses that include the rhinoviruses that cause the common cold, and enteroviruses like poliovirus.Paramyxoviruses, negative stranded enveloped viruses that include measles, mumps, and Respiratory Syncitial Viruses.Flaviviruses, enveloped, positive stranded viruses that include arthropod-transmitted viruses such s yellow fever, dengue, and ZikaFiloviruses, enveloped negative stranded viruses that include Ebola virus

No. Only RNA viruses that utilize DNA at some point in their life cycle are termed retroviruses and they are all found in Group VI of the Baltimore Classification. Groups I, II, and VII are DNA based viruses and RNA is not their primary carrier of genetic information. Groups III, IV, and V, also are RNA viruses, but they do not use DNA at any point during their lifecycle. They are collectively termed riboviruses but the term is rather vague as the riboviruses are most definitely polyphyletic and different groups function in rather different ways. See Also: Baltimore classification - Wikipedia
